intro: Onochilis tinctoria, commonly known as the red paintbrush, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its striking red to orange flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, winged seeds that are dispersed by the wind. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Botanically, it belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is valued for its ornamental beauty and ecological role in supporting pollinators.
